title: China criticises Apple for app that tracks Hong Kong police
text:
Apple has become the latest company targeted by China over products or comments related to anti-government protests in Hong Kong.

People's Daily, the mouthpiece of China's ruling Communist Party, criticised the tech giant today over a smartphone app that allows activists to report police movements.

HKmap.live, designed by an outside supplier and available on Apple's online store, 'facilitates illegal behavior,' the newspaper said in a commentary.

'Is Apple guiding Hong Kong thugs?' the newspaper said.

The op-ed came as America's National Basketball Association (NBA) faces backlashes from Beijing after the general manager of Houston Rockets Daryl Morey voiced his support for the four months long demonstrations.

While Mr Morey apologised over his tweet, NBA's boss Adam Silver said he supported and would protect his employees' freedom of speech - remarks that have enraged China.

The anti-government protests in Hong Kong have been going on for four months. Millions of people have taken to the streets to demand wider democratic reforms. Pictured, a supporter of Edward Leung, a jailed activist, holds a banner outside the High Court in Hong Kong today

The movement has become increasingly violent. Pictured, members of media (right) were hit by petrol bombs during a clash between protesters and police in Wai Chai on Sunday

'Apple jumped into this on its own and mixed together business with politics and commercial activity with illegal activities,' People's Daily slammed the US tech company in a commentary

Beijing has pressed companies including Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways to take the government's side against the protests, which are in their fourth month.

Apple didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.

HKmap.live allows users to report police locations, use of tear gas and other details that are added to a regularly updated map. Another version is available for smartphones that use the Android operating system.

The programme also has a web-based version.

The app's developers last week claimed that Apple had rejected the app during a reviewing process.

They said on Twitter the process had resumed after an appeal.

HKmap.live is currently available in Apple's app store as pictured. Another version is available for smartphones that use the Android operating system. A web-based version is also running

A protester wearing a Guy Fawkes mask uses her mobile phone during a demonstration in Hong Kong on Wednesday. Tech-savvy activists have been using software to organise rallies

Asked whether the Chinese government had asked Apple to remove HKmap.live from its online store, a foreign ministry spokesman said he had no information about that.

'What I can tell you is that these radical, violent crimes in Hong Kong have seriously challenged the legal system and social order in Hong Kong, threatened the safety of Hong Kong residents' lives and property, and undermined the prosperity and stability of Hong Kong,' said the spokesman, Geng Shuang.

'Anyone who has a conscience and justice should resist and oppose instead of supporting and indulging those actions,' Geng said at a regular news briefing.

The picture shows an icon of Apple app 'HKmap.live' which is designed by an outside supplier

Protesters set barricade on fire at a demonstration in Causeway Bay district on Sunday

The demonstrations began over a proposed extradition law and expanded to include other grievances and demands for greater democracy.

Criticism of Apple followed government attacks starting last weekend on the Houston Rockets manager Daryl Morey's post in support of the protesters. China's state TV has canceled broadcasts of NBA games.

'Apple jumped into this on its own and mixed together business with politics and commercial activity with illegal activities,' People's Daily said.

The newspaper warned Apple might be damaging its reputation with Chinese consumers.

Brands targeted in the past by Beijing have been subjected to campaigns by the entirely state-controlled press to drive away consumers or disruptive investigations by tax and other regulators.

Yesterday, another Chinese state-controlled newspaper Global Times issued a stern warning to global brands in response to the controversy surrounding NBA and Daryl Morey, telling worldwide firms to stay away from politics.

Mr Morey on Friday tweeted 'Fight For Freedom. Stand With Hong Kong' before swiftly deleting the post and apologising to China.

Global Times claimed it was 'ridiculous' to suggest that Mr Morey was entitled to free speech.

'The incident shows an expanding worldwide culture gap,' it wrote.

'I did not intend my tweet to cause any offence to Rockets fans and friends of mine in China,' Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey (pictured) tweeted as he apologised to Beijing

Morey's initial tweet included an image captioned: 'Fight For Freedom. Stand With Hong Kong'

China has long been critical to Apple's business.

The mainland is Apple's second-biggest market after the United States, but CEO Tim Cook has said since 2013 it will eventually become No. 1.

Sales in China declined 4 per cent in the quarter ending in June, but that was an improvement over the 25 per cent contraction in the first half of its fiscal year.

The National Basketball Association (NBA) from the United States has been slammed in China after Houston Rockets' manager voiced support for Hong Kong. Pictured, two men sit outside an NBA store in Beijing, the capital city of the country proven to be a huge sports market

Adam Silver, Commissioner of the NBA, has shown his support for freedom of speech amid the controversy surrounding a post by Daryl Morey regarding the demonstrations in Hong Kong

'This recklessness will cause much trouble for Apple,' People's Daily said. 'Apple needs to think deeply.'

Apple also is an important asset to China.

Most of its iPhones and tablet computers are assembled in Chinese factories that employ hundreds of thousands of people. Chinese vendors supply components for Mac Pro computers that are assembled in Texas.

Supporters surround a police bus carrying political activist Edward Leung as it leaves the High Court in Hong Kong on Wednesday. Several hundred masked protestors chanting for revolution have gathered at Hong Kong's High Court for the appeal hearing of Leung

Hong Kong jailed activist Edward Leung (left) is escorted by Correctional Services officers in a prison van as he arrives high court for his sentence appeal in Hong Kong on Wednesday

The former British colony has been rocked by months of protests over a now-withdrawn extradition bill that would have allowed people to be sent to mainland China for trial but have evolved into calls for democracy.

Chaos have escalated since last Friday after the city's leader invoked a colonial-era emergency law to criminalise the wearing of masks during demonstrations.

Thousands of protesters have taken to the streets with their face covered in defiance of the ban.

A supporter holds a placard with picture of Hong Kong activist Edward Leung and Chinese words which mean 'I am a protector of Edward Leung' outside the High Court in Hong Kong

Supporters of Hong Kong activist Edward Leung, hold up their hands to represent the protesters' five demands outside the High Court in Hong Kong on Wednesday

Hundreds of masked protesters yelling 'Revolution Now!' today crammed the sidewalk in front of Hong Kong's High Court to support a jailed pro-democracy activist.

Edward Leung was sentenced to six years in prison for his part in a violent night-long clash with police over illegal street food hawkers two years ago. He appealed to the decision in a hearing.

As a prison service bus with mesh-covered windows drove 28-year-old Leung away after the hearing, supporters pressed up against the vehicle, briefly blocking traffic, and held five fingers up in their air.

That symbolises the five demands of Hong Kong's protest movement.

The fate of his appeal was not immediately clear.
description: Apple has become the latest firm targeted by China over products or comments related to anti-government protests in Hong Kong. State paper People's Daily criticised the tech giant today.
